Most of them are theories and models which contain considerable amount of graphs, the good thing is there are not much maths, just simple computation. There may be one or two equations require differentiation, but you can deal with it even you never learned differentiation.

Ch4 The Market Forces of Supply and Demand
Ch5 Elasticity and Its Application

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Siu's teaching is pretty good. He uses daily examples to explain those economic theories and models. He is also willing to answer any questions after the lessons.

TAs are fine, they usually give brief summary of the chapter and explain some hard questions in the problem sets. If you are not going to attend tutorials, at least download the files TA share at the beginning of tutorials cuz those files will not show up in canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading methods
1.
10% problem sets
15%+15% TWO midterm exams
60% final exams

2.
10% problem sets
20% ONE midterm exam with higher score
70% final exams

Midterms:
Open book online test, 80 mins to finish 50 MCs

Final:
Open book written test, 2 hrs to finish 4 short Qs and 2 long Qs


Midterms are relatively easy and it's your best chance to get a good grade because the final is completely different.

For final exam, short questions will give you a scenario, some of them looks like open-ended questions and the others have strict answers.
The long questions are similar to the problem set with many subparts.
The time for final exam is tight and you don't really have time to check the PPTs. So it's important to familiarise the problem sets questions and some of the important slides in PPT (such as the maths part in Ch17). In my case, I missed half the last question.

My grades:
1st midterm: 36/50, mean 35/50, sd 6.35
2nd midterm: 37/50, mean 36.5/50, sd 6.3
Final: 60/100, mean 56.7/100, median 57/100, sd 17.6
Assignment: full 10%
Letter grade: B

As long as you submitted the 9 problem sets, you will get full marks on assignment because the prof. and TAs are not really checking the problem sets, they just give you full marks if you have submitted.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is pretty light.

Only 1 question set per week, you have 2 chances to miss the question sets because the contribution on grades only count on 9 out of 11 question sets.

light. you can get full marks on quizzes if you complete them all. For assignments, you can take the online solutions for reference :), easy to get full marks.

The only workload is the revision part. It is complete ok if u didn't pay attention to class because you have textbook (to save money, get the online one).

I suggest you can read the book to clarify your understanding. Please pay extra attention to the relationship between terms, for e.g. when A increase, B must increase (there are a lot of relationships, make sure you don't get mess up).

Also, pay attention to the definitions, you do not have to memorise, but you need to be clear about them as they will be covered in the MC questions.

Lastly, don't just focus on the quantity of questions when you do practice. There are practices provided by the TA, if you have limited time, I suggest you to focus working on those practices and get familiar with them. If you listen to me, I believe you will at least get a B. Thanks for reading. Good luck :)

reviews.title: Get tortured if you're a math noob!!!
reviews.comment_content:
The content starts off very easy but gets much harder as it progresses. Those marked with üî∑ are easy topics. But starting from topics marked with üî∂, such as the cost curves in firm production and firms' decision under different market structures, rigorous mathematical and graphical reasoning are required. In these topics, you will see different curves intersecting seemingly randomly like a fountain (but indeed with a rationale behind), and what math noobs can do is to stare at the lecture ppts and remain puzzled. So this course isn't really for math noobs.

Topics included:
üî∑ Ten Principles of Economics
üî∑ Thinking Like an Economist

üî∑ The Market Forces of Supply and Demand

üî∂ Monopoly

The final exam was an absolute mind blower compared to the strikingly easy midterms. It required us to answer long questions with full economic analysis backed by graphs and economic concepts. Algebraic equations are needed in the oligopoly part and those who are bad at algebra can screw up the final exam easily.

DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE if you're a math noob!!!

reviews.author: Heliumet
reviews.title: This course makes me feel interested in Economics
reviews.comment_content: The course is well designed for students like me who haven't learnt Economics before. It covers basics concepts like opportunity costs, producer and consumer surplus, taxes and subsidies, private and public goods, game theory etc. It is designed in a manner that you would find it interesting and not too tough to learn. Topics can easily be related to daily life and you can understand from examples.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Li is a good lecturer. She explains concepts clearly and is willing to answer questions from students. Sometimes if we have discussions on the topic in the chatroom, she is also willing to respond. Both she and the TAs are easily reachable after class, which means if you encounter any questions when doing assignments or checking exam answers, you can always reach out to them easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final score of the course is the higher of the two scores obtained from the following calculation methods:

Method 1:
Assignment: 15% (ignore the lowest 2 scores)
Midterm 1: 12.5%
Midterm 2: 12.5%
Final exam: 60%

Method 2:
Assignment 15% (same as above)
The higher midterm: 22.5%
Final exam: 62.5%

Basically, if you do particularly well in one of the midterm or final, method 2 will be in favor of you.

Due to online mode of teaching and exams, the two midterms consist of 50 MCs each. This makes the mean rather high (about 80%), so revisions and hard work is really needed. Exam is designed to be long and demanding (which is the original wordings of Prof. Li who says this could increase the opportunity cost of cheating, which I think is reasonable). Turns out the mean is quite low (about 50%). As everyone has a not-so-high score, you don't need a very high marks to get a prominent grade.

At last, attendance is not counted towards the grade, but it is not advised to skip the lessons. They are really useful.

For me, I have done all assignments and +1sd in one of the midterm and the final, and turns out an A grade, which is good enough for me as a newcomer in the world of Economics.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is not light, but reasonable. Throughout the semester, you have to do selected questions from up to 15 chapters. Usually each assignment has a deadline separated by one week so you don't need to rush them all the way. The questions are selected to be applicable and can be used as a revision of the topic in class. An assignment usually takes 1 to 1.5 hours to complete. Going through Microeconomics from 0 to 1 is not easy, but I think this course serves the purpose.

reviews.comment_content:
Concepts like gains from trade, demand - supply curves, government and markets, cost curves, perfectly competitive markets, monopolies, oligopolies are covered. Content I'm guessing would be easy for students who have a basic background in economics from high school.

For those who are thinking of taking the course as an introduction into the world of economics, the course may start off easy but gets harder as it progresses. The prescribed text, Principles of Microeconomics by Mankiw is really good to help grasp concepts.

Come to class if you just want to be entertained or want "life advice" (yes those are air quotes) from a professor who loves to boast about his achievements albeit his bad grade in ECON2103 when he did the course as a student.
If you come to class thinking you really want to learn something as a beginner to economics, you surely will be *disappointed* as sleep is naturally induced in his lectures. reviews.comment_grading:

By personal experience, the midterms are easy to score above mean + sd in if you have done the content well (lecture slides and textbook), mean is pretty high too. Final (cumulative syllabus) is hard in the sense some questions have multiple concepts combined that may make it hard to answer in the long questions. Marking is strict by the TAs and it is hard to argue with them in short questions and long questions.

*Terrible choice* as a common core or business minor requirement. Return on investment? Not good. There are better courses out there for you believe me.

The contents are actually very intuitive, but still useful in daily-life. Things like demand & supply, Nash equilibrium and Game Theory, and different markets and its equilibriums is what I think is basic knowledge, and its very good to know if you have not done your own studies on them.

The course outline states:
As an introductory course, this course will cover the fundamental concepts and tools involved in microeconomic analysis. Economics provides a powerful way of thinking that helps you
to understand many human and social phenomena. Real-world examples and cases will be used as much as possible to enhance your understanding.

Mean: 69.1 out of 100

The HWs never change over the semesters, so you could just search it up on Google or ask previous seniors who have taken the course. There are:
Midterms (MC)
Problem Set (for each chapter, get 100% as long as you submit - but be careful as some people get caught submitting blank documents / their friend's work / one document for different problem sets)
Finals

Scheme 1:
Midterm 1 + Midterm 2: 22.5% + 22.5%
Final Exam: 45%
Problem Sets: 10%

Final Exam: 55%

reviews.comment_teaching:
Wing is actually the best professor I encountered in UST. He is able to explain all the economic concept in a 'raw' way, even a primary student can understand.

His digression is not boring at all and you can learn interesting life stories from him.

Wing prepares his own ppts and they are sometimes different to the textbook. My suggestion is to read the textbook before attending Wing's lectures.

TA Teresa prepares optional tutorials every week. She actually provide very detailed notes and concise explanation (though I recommend you actually attend the lectures because Wing like to test things on the ppt)

Like the others said, if you like learning by grinding papers, you will be disappointed because Wing emphasises 'way of economic thinking'. Also, like the others said, Wing is very pushy and can come off as intimidating, because he wants perfection in lecture discussions.

Right now the only thing I remember is Wing and Albert are producing meat and potatoes in a two goods, two producer world...
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading schemes, count higher of the 2.
Scheme 1. 10% homework + 2x15% midterms + 60% final
Scheme 2. 10% homework + 20% higher of the 2 midterms + 70% final.

Heard the others say if above 1 SD is A range, and above 2 SD is A+.

Homework: Count n-2 amount of problem sets issued. Doesn't matter if it's right or wrong. This semester total of 12 sets were issued.

Midterms: Non cumulative and covers Part 1 and 2 respectively. Both were supposed to be 80 minute, 50 MC questions but Wing removed 10 questions in MT due to student complaint
Midterm 1 (/50). Mean: 36.75, Median: 37, SD: 6.44
Midterm 2 (/40). Mean: 31.9, Median: 33, SD: 5.3

Many people complained that MT 1 was too hard so Wing removed 10 questions from MT 2.

Final: Mixture of short and long questions in 2 hours (its cumulative). Must use graph and diagram in explanation!!! The technique to getting good score is to answer in a way that Wing wants you to answer (meaning just getting the answer 'correct' is not enough)
Final (/100). Mean: 59.5, Median: 59, SD: 16.3

Personally I get 37/50 in MT 1 (totally clueless because I was not used to Wing's teachings), 37/40 for MT 2, and 89/100 in the final. Finally get A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
One problem set every week for each chapter. You can just search online for answers, but I recommend actually attempting the questions first, because they can be quite similar to the final exam.

Older reviews say you can hand in blank pdf, but I would not do this, because Wing said he will check if you actually answered the questions.

If you spent appropriate time on this course, you can excel in it.

NOTE: Wing said that Nash equilibrium and deriving cournot duopoly have a high chance of repeating in the final... It's probably true.

reviews.comment_teaching: the atmosphere is quite relaxing and he often make appropriate jokes to give examples for the theories presented.
reviews.comment_grading: don't be scared by the amount of points required for each question, it is quite easy to get points. graphs are very important.

reviews.author: Low Jin
reviews.comment_content:
2 mid terms, 1 final and 10~11 assignments.
Mid term - MCQs, 40 questions
Final - MCQs, essay questions, long questions(explanation, graphs, calculations)
Assignments - MCQs, short questions(explanation, graphs, calculations)

reviews.comment_teaching:
A funny and caring lecturer. He always emphasizes on the understanding of concepts instead of memorizing them. He provided various real life examples for students to better understand the concepts.

The most interesting part of the lecture would be the time when he kept asking us "why" questions. Do take notes, it will help in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Generally should be fine if we go through the textbook plus lecture notes and complete the assignments. Mean ~ B

Assignments: 10%
Mid term 1 + Mid term 2: 22.5% + 22.5%
Final: 45%

Grading Calculation 2 (for one midterm) :
Assignments: 10%
Mid term 1 or Mid term 2: 35%
Final: 55%

The overall score for this course will be the higher score computed from these two calculations.
reviews.comment_workload: There are around 10~11 assignments( 1 for each lecture, questions extracted from textbook). Although the assignments we submitted are not marked, they are really useful in preparing for exams as well as for our own learning. Suggested solutions will be given after the deadline for each assignment.

reviews.author: Illumi
reviews.comment_content:
Very interesting.
principle of micro-economics together with the basic of game theory, which is the professor's own research area.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Woo Young is  a great professor! He teaches effectively and attractively. He's patient to answer questions and students are welcome to walk in his office. Whats more, he always have lunch with us before class!
He tell us his own stories to encourage us. He's really hard working.
He also organize experiments. Students can earn about 100hkd per hour for making decision in games designed by him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade!
I've got 182 out of 200 in midtem, and 186 out of 200 in final and got A.
My friend got around 150 in midterm and about 170 in final and got A.
Woo Young said he's trying to give as much A grades as possible, likely 20%.
It's easy to get good grade if you go to more than 2/3 of the classes and do homework carefully. (homework is chosen from past paper, and some of the problem will appear on exams.)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think it's OK. We have 19 problems to solve in total (each has about 4 sub-problems). We submitted the answers in four parts, and the forth part is not compulsory.
Both Woo Young and TA will talk about the questions in lecture and tutorial.
(homework is chosen from past paper, and some of the problem will appear on exams)

reviews.author: Jessica123455
reviews.comment_content: The content is very attractive and interesting and the professor organize the teaching well. But it is slightly more difficult than other professor's lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lim Woo Young is a very interesting and humour professor. His teaching is quite good because he himself is very well educated( He will possibly show his CV at the last lecture like what he did this semester to us) and can explain things clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is Okay and the final is very( really very) important. He will put some of the questions in the homework and lecture notes into exam paper.
reviews.comment_workload: I Think it is okay. The homework calls for some time and energy but it is acceptable because a group of up to 5 is formed to complete the assignment.

reviews.author: CRDZY
reviews.title: Pretty hard class, pay attention.
reviews.comment_content:
The content will teach you extensively on Microeconomics with a small dabbling in Game theory and a hint at advanced classes in the future should you choose to take them.
Pay close attention to the earlier modules as they will definitely be needed as a strong foundation for the later topics like Government regulations or market efficiency.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lim is a very comprehensive teacher. He's super enthusiastic and will regularly try to engage the class. He'll slowly lose steam if he doesn't get responses. Try to engage him for better results. He uses a lot of examples from the textbook for either reference or synchronizations. He will however, give more variations for his answers if you are unclear or ask again. Don't be afraid to ask him if you don't understand cause he'll speak quite quickly to cover as many topics as possible before exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading isn't done by him cause it's a class of 400 plus students. It'll honestly depend on the TAs that you get. If you get one that follows the book very closely, you may lose credits despite doing the correct working but getting the wrong answer. You will need to fight for your grading with them in terms of your assignments and sometimes even approach Prof. Lim directly for it.

Every point counts, trust me.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is mostly self study. However, the assignments are done in groups. These groups are self assigned so make sure you teammates are ones who either know content or you know will work for the answer. The questions are comprehensive and pretty difficult. MAKE SURE YOU DO IT. The examinations are based off the questions that he gives for assignments. Do this and you will obtain a high grade during the exams. Learn this early on and ace that exam which takes up 90% of your final grade.

reviews.author: Ronald Yip
reviews.comment_content: The course is adequate and fundamental to students without economics background. And the concepts of this course is not so difficult to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Woo Young's English is approachable. His explanation of economics is good and his teaching is easy to following. If you have any question, you may find help in tutorial section.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite good. Final exam is so easy and some repeat your assignment. If you really concentrated in lecture, I believe you can get 90%+ in final (I got nearly full marks). Therefore, the key for high grade would be in mid-term exam and homework. PS: I got A+.

For everyone who's not a born-genius, an actual workaholic, or being controlled by grades in order to satisfy our family's perception of being a genius full of success, then just do your best and you'll get commonly a B.

reviews.comment_workload:

Although a lot of the questions were available online, it took me hours to complete each (10 questions each with multiple sub-questions), but in the end they helped me to understand the concepts and the exam. PS2 required me to draw like 10 graphics (annoying since I had to scan each one and AirDrop it lmao). Start doing it a week before the deadline at the very least.

IMO you need to understand deeply the concepts and relationships within (all of the exams were open book exams for me, so no need to memorize). Tutorials are optional, but make sure to practice from the tutorial question sets bcs some of them will appear in the exams. Good luck!

While many would argue that Professor Siu, Kam Wing goes off topic often, I would use that as a strength in his teaching, as usually he would go off topic to help support his teaching and add humour to what we are learning. It really helps us remember the content and stay engaged in class. As this course also involves some calculus and basic mathematics, his way of teaching really does help and it really is nice to get some words of wisdom for life in general here and there.

I only have two criticisms for his teaching. One would be his lack of explanation on how he would grade the finals (how we should format our answers for the short questions). Whereas the second is his pacing for some classes. Since we had spent about two to three lessons on just the principals of economics instead of just one (I thought one would be enough, but it was just stretched because of some unnecessary and repeated but rephrased questions asked in class). Due to this, we had to have two extra lessons during the study week or late in the evening on random days.

On another note, GUO, Bing's tutorials are very well structured and straight to the point. it is a great revision class.

reviews.comment_content:
My advice: NEVER TAKE THIS COURSE IN FALL SEMESTER!!
Too many senior year & non-local students taking this course. The mean is so high!!!!!! You should wait until spring semester and register this course if you want! For junior-year students, you may not take my advice, but you have to face the challenges by yourself!

The content is some basic economic ideas that maybe useful in the future when working outside, regardless of any position you are.

Lecture Schedule:
L1 Ten Principles of Economics
L2 Thinking Like an Economist
L3-L5 Interdependence & the Gains from Trade
L5-L6 The Market Forces of Supply & Demand
L7-L9 Elasticity and Its Application
Midterm 1--include L1-L8, elasticities of demand only for the last topic.
L9-L10 Consumers, Producers, and the Efficiency of Markets
L11-L12 Government Meets Market (Part I)
L13 Government Meets Market (Part II)
L14-L16 The Costs of Production

L16-L18 Firms in Competitive Markets
L19-L20 Monopoly
L21-22 Oligopoly (some pages are skipped)
Final--comprehensive, i.e. from L1-L22.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor has some Chinese accent, but you can clearly understand what she is talking about. However, she teaches in a very fast pace, and I cannot follow it at first...though it is better for me to follow after I catch her teaching pace...

She is strict in class talking, only allows in break (which she allows 5-10 minutes break in EVERY lesson). She does not allow any noise, except asking her questions during lessons! Sometimes, she plays videos that may help you understand more about economic concepts. AND she usually uses both writing and PPT to teach, some additional concepts are taught in class.

Peter, the TA, is VERY VERY slow in marking papers and grading. He always chatted with some other staff in exams, and I was distracted so much. Hence, if you can, sit at the back!

However, Peter is nice to answer any questions, especially during the paper checking sessions (which will be held after midterms & exam), but it is quite hard to find him by office. I think it is better to email him.

Scheme 2: Best Midterms (30%)+Final (50%)+10 Online Quizzes (10%)+ 3 HWs (10%).
